metadata.titleEn: Geochemical data of Jiacuo granodiorites in the Southern Qiangtang block, central Tibet
metadata.description: The data set includes major and trace elements, whole rock Sr – Nd isotope, zircon Hf-O isotope and zircon U-Pb age data of granodiorite. The samples were collected from the granodiorite in the Jiacuo area of the Southern Qiangtang block, central Tibet. Zircon U-Pb dating data were obtained by laser ablation inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry. The major and trace geochemical data of the whole rock are obtained by X-ray fluorescence spectrometry and inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry. The whole rock Sr – Nd isotopes were obtained by sample separation and purification multi receiver inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS). Hf isotopes of zircons were obtained by laser ablation inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry. Through the data obtained, we can define the age, origin and deep dynamic mechanism of magmatism in the region, and provide an understanding of the Jurassic tectonic background of the South Qiangtang block.
metadata.instructions: All data are stored in Excel file. The file name "ZirUPb.xls" represents zircon U-Pb geochronology data. The file name "ZirHf-O.xls" represents zircon Hf and O isotope data. The name of the file "WRMajTra" represents the major and trace geochemical data of the whole rock. The file name "WRIso" represents the whole rock isotopic geochemical data.

authorList.unitEn: Guangzhou Institute of Geochemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences

literatureList.titleEn: Zircon U–Pb geochronology and Sr–Nd–Hf–O isotope geochemistry of Late Jurassic granodiorites in the southern Qiangtang block, Tibet: Remelting of ancient mafic lower crust in an arc setting?
literatureList.referenceEn: Sun, P., Dan, W., Wang, Q., Tang, G. J., Ou, Q., Hao, L. L., & Jiang, Z. Q. (2020). Zircon U–Pb geochronology and Sr–Nd–Hf–O isotope geochemistry of Late Jurassic granodiorites in the southern Qiangtang block, Tibet: Remelting of ancient mafic lower crust in an arc setting?. Journal of Asian Earth Sciences, 192, 104235.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the characteristics of data collection methods used to analyze geological samples in the context of granitoid research?
Feature Specification.Answer: laser ablation-inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry, zircon U-Pb geochronological data, X-ray fluorescence spectrometry, inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry, whole-rock major and trace geochemical data, multi-collector inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry, whole-rock Sr–Nd isotopic analyses, zircon Hf isotopic analyses

Interpretation.Question: What insights can be drawn about the magmatic processes and tectonic setting of the Jurassic period in the South Qiangtang block based on the geochemical and isotopic data collected from granodiorite samples?
Interpretation.Answer: The geochemical and isotopic data, including whole-rock major and trace elements, whole-rock Sr–Nd isotopes, zircon Hf-O isotopes, and zircon U–Pb ages, can help delineate the timing, genesis, and deep dynamic mechanisms of magmatic activity in the region. These insights contribute to understanding the tectonic setting of the South Qiangtang block during the Jurassic period.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors could lead to variations in the geochemical data of granodiorite rocks collected from the central Tibetan Plateau, specifically in the Nam Co area?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Variations in the geochemical data of granodiorite rocks collected from the central Tibetan Plateau, specifically in the Nam Co area, could be caused by differences in data collection methods such as the use of X-ray fluorescence spectrometry and inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry, the precision of equipment like laser ablation-inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry, sample collection techniques, and the natural heterogeneity of the rock formations.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential outcomes on the understanding of Jurassic tectonic settings of the southern Qiangtang block when utilizing geochemical, isotopic, and zircon U-Pb age data collected through various spectrometry methods?
Causal Consequence.Answer: By utilizing geochemical, isotopic, and zircon U-Pb age data collected through methods such as laser ablation-inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry and X-ray fluorescence spectrometry, researchers can better define the magmatic activity's timing, origins, and the deep dynamic mechanisms in the region. This comprehensive data collection approach provides insights into the Jurassic tectonic settings of the southern Qiangtang block.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the intended goal behind collecting geochemical and isotopic data from granodiorite samples in the central Tibetan Plateau's southern Qiangtang block?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal is to determine the age, origin, and deep dynamic mechanisms of magmatism in the region, as well as to understand the tectonic setting of the southern Qiangtang block during the Jurassic period.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the specific instrumental and procedural steps involved in collecting and analyzing geochemical and isotopic data from granodiorite samples in the central southern Qiangtang block, and how do these methods help understand the magmatic processes and tectonic background?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The geochemical and isotopic data from granodiorite samples in the central southern Qiangtang block are collected and analyzed using a series of instrumental and procedural steps. Zircon U-Pb age data are obtained through laser ablation-inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (LA-ICP-MS). Whole-rock major and trace geochemical data are analyzed using X-ray fluorescence (XRF) spectrometer and inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS). Whole-rock Sr-Nd isotopes are determined through sample separation, purification, and multi-collector inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (MC-ICP-MS). Zircon Hf isotopes are acquired using LA-ICP-MS. These methods collectively allow researchers to constrain the timing, origin, and deep dynamic mechanisms of magmatism in the area and provide insights into the Jurassic tectonic setting of the southern Qiangtang block.
